answers.answer: Hello Joe,I am glad it was my day to answer questions!  I happen to be one of those very protective, cautious moms.My son is now 10-1/2.  He was diagnosed at age 3.  (He started the pump a year ago) My daughter (not living with diabetes) is 6-1/2.  The balancing act can be a difficult one.  I know that sometimes my daughter gets jealous because my boy needs this extra care.I will share my feelings and then I will get to support for your wife.I have a major problem with anxiety.  It is very hard even sending my son to school because I am giving up that control, but it gets better as far as the separation.  My heart does jump when my cell phone rings and it is the school, but I deal with it.  I have slept in my son's bed or sometimes in my daughter's room (because hers is closer to my son's than mine and my husband's) on MANY nights.  My husband kept asking me when I was going to come back to our bed.  I think once I told him, "When they find a CURE!"There are support groups out there.  Your wife NEEDS to interact with other moms like me who understand her.for legal reasons we cannot post an Answer to their Question on this message board. However, suggest that they navigate to the JDRF Online Diabetes Support Team and ask their Question there.  Give them these navigation instructions for getting an Answer to their Question.Please ask her to fill out the form on the page below.  It does not mean you have to be new to diabetes, but it is a place for one on one email support.  She will be matched up with someone like myself.  I would love to help her.  Also, just being put in touch with your local chapter of JDRF can help.  They have info. on support groups, etc.Visit http://www.jdrf.org/index.cfm?page_id=103451Please urge her to do so.  One on one suppport can help her to feel that she is not alone and possibly another mom (like me) can share with her ideas on how handle certain aspects of her life.(Since my son was diagnosed, he has only been with my parents, at school and at diabetes camp - I understand not wanting to be away from him - your wife just needs support right now to help with her stress and anxiety.)As far as dealing with aspects of "normal life", it stopped being normal, I guess you could say, but I will do my best to take care of both of my children to the best of my ability and I feel strongly that in our children's lifetime there will be a CURE or soemthing VERY close to one that will alleviate a lot of anxiety.It has been over 7-1/2 years for us and I know I am nuttier than my husband because I have been around the kids more while he is at work.I urge you to talk to your wife about the online diabetes support team.  If not, you can fill the form out and still receive some individual help.http://www.jdrf.org/index.cfm?page_id=103451I hope that your wife and I get connected through the page above.SS

I would also likely be labelled as one of those overprotective Mom's.  Our son was diagnosed at 12 months of age and thus the saga began.  I didn't sleep through a night for many years, always testing to ensure that his blood sugar wasn't going too low during the night, he went everywhere with us or we stayed home to ensure his safety, routine and good health.  Our saving grace was having 2 people (my mother and a niece) that we "trained" so that eventually as he got a little older we could go out for evenings etc. It was a real treat to have these times although I must admit that sometimes I felt guilty that I got a break from the routine, that our little guy could never take.  Once he was off to school, I lobbied hard and got an Educational Assistant assigned specifically to him who stayed in the classroom, assisted him with blood glucose monitoring and snacks and lunches.  The school was fabulous in supporting our sons health. This really helped me gain a level of comfort when he was out of my sight.  He is now 15 and I still keep close tabs on him and think of him lots through each and every day while he is at school, at a friends or whatever.I think it is only natural for a Mom who is well educated in the importance of good control and routine to take this very seriously, and probably sometimes to the point of it consuming one's own life, but as time goes on, and routine is well established, we Moms might have some more relaxed days.All I can suggest is take each day at a time, appreciate the fact that your child is getting the best care possible and help whenever you can and draw on the support of family or friends who you would feel comfortable spending time with your child.All the best to you.

I think most mothers of Type I diabetics must fall into that category.  When my daughter was diagnosed at age 7 I never thought we'd get back to any type of normal life and really we haven't, we've just changed our definition of what normal is. I barely remember having any contact with my other daughter for months after Emma was first diagnosed and I know I put a lot of responsiblity on my older daughter that she would not have had if her sister was not a diabetic.  It has been 5 years and I can honestly tell you I still only sleep 4-5 hours a night and I work a full time 9-5 job outside the home Monday through Friday at a major company.  My daughter is my number one priority and everything else comes second.  I stay up until at least 1:00 a.m. every night so that I can check her sugar at 10:00 and then again 2 hours later.  My daughter did go on a pump less than a year ago and this has helped in keeping her sugars under control and has stabalized her to the point that I probably don't need to check her at midnight anymore but, it's tough to let that go.  The few times I have tried to go to bed and not check her at midnight, I wake up at 2 or 3 and can't get back to sleep until I go in and check her.  She is 12 years old now and went on her first sleep over this year, only after she got the pump.  Before that there was no way I'd let her be away from me.It took a huge toll on my mariage initially because I was consumed with keeping her under control, strees and worry.  It's something that just can't be helped.  Your wife understands that at this point in your daughter's life, she is soley responsible for keeping your daughter under control, the stress and anxiety of this can be completely overwhelming.  I don't think my husband really understood how difficult it is to keep a type I diabetic under good control either.  It's a CONSTANT battle.  I did finally have to be away from home on business and my husband HAD to take the control of our daughter's care.  This was before she was on the pump so it was more difficult then.  Believe me leaving her alone with him was probably the hardest thing I had to do but it was also one of the best things.  He failed miserably at keeping her under control and realized how very, very difficult and frustrating this diesease can be.There is really nothing you can say that will make her less stressed at this point.  As things become more routine, that stress level will go down, but never disappear.  Going on a pump will be a big help but initially that too can be very stressful.  It takes some time to get the pump in tune with the diabetic.Please be patient, supportive and understanding.  It will take time, lots of time.  Hang in there!

Joey,I applaud your reaching out for help for your wife.  This indicates to me you care alot about her well being.  Please find ways to help her and your child.  Become involved hour by hour and learn as much as you can about your child and his/her diabetes.  You may well have already done this and if so, that is great!  Dig deeper and ask them both questions.  Your child will be happy another adult cares enough to find out what he/she is thinking and feeling.  Your wife will LOVE you for your interest in her and for taking more responsibility for your childs care.  I agree that your wife would be helped tremendously by reaching out to the JDRF Online Support Team.  You would both be put in touch with other parents who truly do understand and whose feet have trod in the same place yours have.I am not a professional, but I feel as though I should be because of my life experience.  My son was one when he was diagnosed and back then, there was little known about infant diabetics.  We trailblazed together and it was very, very rough.  One problem was what was called emotional overlay.  This occured because I had very little support and I was scared out of my mind.  Everyone feels better about the circumstances they are in when they see light at the end of the tunnel no matter how small.  JDRF was there for me then and they helped alot and they will you as well.

question: I work a lot of hours.Wife stays home takes care of our 4 year old daughter w/ type1 in addition to another 2 year old girl that is healthy.The stress of her dealing with and managing our j.d. daughter is driving her to places that scare me.She doesn't sleep, and cannot ever leave her side because she is worried about her blood sugar levels.Our daughter had a quick seizure once. (we quickly got glucagon in her)She was diagnosed 20 months ago and is supposed to go on the pump in october.I am really worried about my wife and need advice on how other extremely caring, cautious, protective mothers have dealed with and mananged a type 1 diabetic and maintained all the other aspects of their normal life.Thanks...Joe***@****
title: To Stay At Home Moms In Charge Of a Type1 Child -  Need guidance.
